Inferring topology of quantum phase space

Leonid Polterovich a
with an appendix by Laurent Charles
Abstract

Does a semiclassical particle remember the phase space topology? We discuss this question in the context of the Berezin-Toeplitz quantization and quantum measurement theory by using tools of topological data analysis. One of its facets involves a calculus of Toeplitz operators with piecewise constant symbol developed in an appendix by Laurent Charles.

1 Introduction

We discuss an application of persistent homology to quantum-classical correspondence, a fundamental principle stating that quantum mechanics contains classical one as the limiting case when the Planck constant ℏPlanck-constant-over-2-pi\hbar tends to 00. Paraphrasing [22, Chapter 7], this means that in this limit, mathematical structures of Hamiltonian dynamics on closed symplectic manifolds are hidden somewhere in the linear algebra and probability of matrix quantum mechanics. While a vast literature explores quantum footprints of dynamical phenomena such as transition to chaos [22], not much is known about the ones of phase space topology. In fact, on the quantum side, topological phenomena can be elusive. For instance, according to the tunneling effect [17], a quantum particle may commute between different connected components of an energy level set in the phase space, thus getting wrong about topology of this set.

In the present note we make a step towards understanding quantum footprints of phase space topology in the framework of quantum measurement theory. We deal with the following problem. Suppose that the phase space of a semiclassical system is equipped with a finite collection of sensors. An experimentalist, having an access to an ensemble of particles, registers each of them at a “nearby” sensor and gathers the statistics. Is it possible to guess homology of the phase space on the basis of the data obtained? We shall show, within a specific probabilistic model of registration, that such a topological inference is feasible provided the sensors form a sufficiently dense net in the phase space and the experimentalist can tune the range of the sensors. Roughly speaking, a sensor z𝑧z has range a𝑎a if it cannot detect particles located at distance ≥aabsent𝑎\geq a from z𝑧z. Here is a sketch of the proposed recipe.

  • 1.

    Take two special values of the range, a<b𝑎𝑏a<b, which depend on local geometry of the sensor network, and which are assumed to be known in advance. Then, for each value of the range s∈{a,b}𝑠𝑎𝑏s\in\{a,b\} perform two consecutive registrations and calculate, for all distinct sensors z𝑧z and w𝑤w, the probability pz​w,ssubscript𝑝𝑧𝑤𝑠p_{zw,s} of registration at z𝑧z and w𝑤w.

  • 2.

    Fix real m>0𝑚0m>0. Form a pair of simplicial complexes Qssubscript𝑄𝑠Q_{s}, s∈{a,b}𝑠𝑎𝑏s\in\{a,b\} whose vertices are the sensors, and whose simplices are formed by subsets σ𝜎\sigma of the vertices with pz​w,s>ℏmsubscript𝑝𝑧𝑤𝑠superscriptPlanck-constant-over-2-pi𝑚p_{zw,s}>\hbar^{m} for all distinct z,w∈σ𝑧𝑤𝜎z,w\in\sigma. Here we assume that the Planck constant ℏPlanck-constant-over-2-pi\hbar is small enough.

  • 3.

    With a right choice of a𝑎a and b𝑏b, Qasubscript𝑄𝑎Q_{a} will be a subset of Qbsubscript𝑄𝑏Q_{b}. The image of the inclusion morphism in homology H​(Qa)→H​(Qb)→𝐻subscript𝑄𝑎𝐻subscript𝑄𝑏H(Q_{a})\to H(Q_{b}) turns out to be isomorphic to the homology of the phase space.

For a rigorous statement, see Theorem 3.3 which is formulated in Section 3 and proved in Section 4. These sections contain brief preliminaries on persistent homology and relevant methods of topological data analysis. The mathematical model of registration is discussed in Sections 2 and 5. Section 6 discusses a possible strategy of inferring the homotopy type of the phase space. It involves a calculus of Toeplitz operators with piecewise constant symbol developed in an appendix by Laurent Charles. The note ends with an outline of further directions. Let us pass to precise formulations.

2 Registration: setting the stage

We assume that the phase space is given by a closed symplectic manifold (M,ω)𝑀𝜔(M,\omega). Our model of the registration procedure [20] involves a finite open cover 𝒰={U1,…,UN}𝒰subscript𝑈1…subscript𝑈𝑁{\mathcal{U}}=\{U_{1},...,U_{N}\} of M𝑀M, considered as a small scale coarse-graining of M𝑀M, and a subordinated partition of unity f1,…,fNsubscript𝑓1…subscript𝑓𝑁f_{1},\ldots,f_{N}. Here fi:M→[0,1]:subscript𝑓𝑖→𝑀01f_{i}:M\to[0,1] is a smooth function supported in Uisubscript𝑈𝑖U_{i} so that ∑ifi=1subscript𝑖subscript𝑓𝑖1\sum_{i}f_{i}=1.

The classical registration procedure assigns to every point z∈M𝑧𝑀z\in M unique i∈ΩN:={1,…,N}𝑖subscriptΩ𝑁assign1…𝑁i\in\Omega_{N}:=\{1,...,N\} with probability fi​(z)subscript𝑓𝑖𝑧f_{i}(z). Thus it provides an answer to the question “to which of the sets Uisubscript𝑈𝑖U_{i} does it belong?” While the question is ambiguous due to overlaps between the sets Uisubscript𝑈𝑖U_{i}, the ambiguity is resolved with the help of the partition of unity. Since fisubscript𝑓𝑖f_{i} is supported in Uisubscript𝑈𝑖U_{i}, the output is “the truth, but not the whole truth”.

Recall that a classical state is a Borel probability measure, say ν𝜈\nu on M𝑀M. One readily calculates (see Section 5 below) the probability piCsubscriptsuperscript𝑝𝐶𝑖p^{C}_{i} that the classical system prepared in a state ν𝜈\nu is registered in Uisubscript𝑈𝑖U_{i}:

piC=∫fi​𝑑ν,subscriptsuperscript𝑝𝐶𝑖subscript𝑓𝑖differential-d𝜈p^{C}_{i}=\int f_{i}d\nu\;, (1)

where C𝐶C stands for classical.

This registration procedure has a natural quantum version in the context of the Berezin-Toeplitz quantization. To this end we assume that the symplectic structure ω𝜔\omega is quantizable, i.e., its cohomology class divided by 2​π2𝜋2\pi is integral. The reader is invited to think of the 2-dimensional sphere of area 2​π2𝜋2\pi, which appears as the classical limit of the high spin quantum particle. The Berezin-Toeplitz quantization is given by a family of finite dimensional complex Hilbert spaces ℋℏsubscriptℋPlanck-constant-over-2-pi\mathcal{H}_{\hbar}, where ℏPlanck-constant-over-2-pi\hbar is the Planck constant considered as a small parameter, together with linear maps Tℏsubscript𝑇Planck-constant-over-2-piT_{\hbar} from 𝒞∞​(M)superscript𝒞𝑀{\mathcal{C}}^{\infty}(M) to the space of Hermitian operators ℒ​(ℋℏ)ℒsubscriptℋPlanck-constant-over-2-pi{\mathcal{L}}(\mathcal{H}_{\hbar}). The maps Tℏsubscript𝑇Planck-constant-over-2-piT_{\hbar}, which are defined by the integration against an ℒ​(ℋℏ)ℒsubscriptℋPlanck-constant-over-2-pi{\mathcal{L}}(\mathcal{H}_{\hbar})-valued positive operator valued measure (POVM), satisfy the quantum-classical correspondence principle which will be reminded in Section 5. The quantum counter-part of the partition of unity f1,…,fNsubscript𝑓1…subscript𝑓𝑁f_{1},...,f_{N} is a POVM on a finite set {1,…,N}1…𝑁\{1,\dots,N\} consisting of Hermitian operators F1,ℏ,…,FN,ℏsubscript𝐹1Planck-constant-over-2-pi…subscript𝐹𝑁Planck-constant-over-2-piF_{1,\hbar},...,F_{N,\hbar} with

Fj,ℏ=Tℏ​(fj)∈ℒ​(ℋℏ).subscript𝐹𝑗Planck-constant-over-2-pisubscript𝑇Planck-constant-over-2-pisubscript𝑓𝑗ℒsubscriptℋPlanck-constant-over-2-piF_{j,\hbar}=T_{\hbar}(f_{j})\in{\mathcal{L}}(\mathcal{H}_{\hbar})\;.

Let 𝒮ℏsubscript𝒮Planck-constant-over-2-pi{\mathcal{S}}_{\hbar} be the set of quantum states, i.e., the positive trace 111 operators from ℒ​(ℋℏ)ℒsubscriptℋPlanck-constant-over-2-pi{\mathcal{L}}(\mathcal{H}_{\hbar}). Recall that every quantum state ρ∈𝒮ℏ𝜌subscript𝒮Planck-constant-over-2-pi\rho\in{\mathcal{S}}_{\hbar} determines a Borel probability measure μρ,ℏsubscript𝜇𝜌Planck-constant-over-2-pi\mu_{\rho,\hbar} on M𝑀M by the formula

∫f​𝑑μρ,ℏ=trace​(Tℏ​(f)​ρ)​∀f∈𝒞∞​(M).𝑓differential-dsubscript𝜇𝜌Planck-constant-over-2-pitracesubscript𝑇Planck-constant-over-2-pi𝑓𝜌for-all𝑓superscript𝒞𝑀\int fd\mu_{\rho,\hbar}={{\rm trace}}(T_{\hbar}(f)\rho)\;\;\forall f\in{\mathcal{C}}^{\infty}(M)\;.

Intuitively speaking, the measure μρ,ℏsubscript𝜇𝜌Planck-constant-over-2-pi\mu_{\rho,\hbar}, which is called the Husimi measure, governs the distribution of a quantum particle in the phase space. By definition, the probability pi,ℏQsubscriptsuperscript𝑝𝑄𝑖Planck-constant-over-2-pip^{Q}_{i,\hbar} of the quantum registration at i𝑖i provided the system is at the state ρ𝜌\rho equals

pi,ℏQ=trace​(Fi,ℏ​ρ)=∫fi​𝑑μρ,ℏ,subscriptsuperscript𝑝𝑄𝑖Planck-constant-over-2-pitracesubscript𝐹𝑖Planck-constant-over-2-pi𝜌subscript𝑓𝑖differential-dsubscript𝜇𝜌Planck-constant-over-2-pip^{Q}_{i,\hbar}={{\rm trace}}(F_{i,\hbar}\rho)=\int f_{i}d\mu_{\rho,\hbar}\;, (2)

in an analogy with the classical equation (1). Here Q𝑄Q stands for quantum.

A key role in our strategy of phase space learning is played by repeated registration: prepare the system in the “maximally mixed state” ρ0subscript𝜌0\rho_{0} and make two consecutive independent registrations. In the classical case the state ρ0subscript𝜌0\rho_{0} is the normalized symplectic volume μ𝜇\mu, and in the quantum case ρ0=1dimℋℏ​1​lsubscript𝜌01dimensionsubscriptℋPlanck-constant-over-2-pi1l\rho_{0}=\frac{1}{\dim\mathcal{H}_{\hbar}}{1\hskip-2.5pt{\rm l}}.

In the classical case, the probability of the outcome i​j𝑖𝑗ij of the repeated registration equals

pi​jC=∫Mfi​fj​𝑑μ,subscriptsuperscript𝑝𝐶𝑖𝑗subscript𝑀subscript𝑓𝑖subscript𝑓𝑗differential-d𝜇p^{C}_{ij}=\int_{M}f_{i}f_{j}d\mu\;, (3)

see Section 5.

In the quantum case, in order to calculate the probability pi​j,ℏQsubscriptsuperscript𝑝𝑄𝑖𝑗Planck-constant-over-2-pip^{Q}_{ij,\hbar} of the outcome i​j𝑖𝑗ij of the repeated registration one has to take into account the quantum state reduction. We assume that the latter is described by the Lüders rule, which will be reminded below in Section 5. We denote by 𝒪​(ℏ∞)𝒪superscriptPlanck-constant-over-2-pi\mathcal{O}(\hbar^{\infty}) a sequence which decays faster than any power of ℏPlanck-constant-over-2-pi\hbar.

Proposition 2.1.

Assume that the system is prepared in the maximally mixed state. Then for the repeated registration

pi​j,ℏQ=trace​(Fi,ℏ​Fj,ℏ)dimℋℏ=pi​jC+𝒪​(ℏ).subscriptsuperscript𝑝𝑄𝑖𝑗Planck-constant-over-2-pitracesubscript𝐹𝑖Planck-constant-over-2-pisubscript𝐹𝑗Planck-constant-over-2-pidimensionsubscriptℋPlanck-constant-over-2-pisubscriptsuperscript𝑝𝐶𝑖𝑗𝒪Planck-constant-over-2-pip^{Q}_{ij,\hbar}=\frac{{{\rm trace}}(F_{i,\hbar}F_{j,\hbar})}{\dim\mathcal{H}_{\hbar}}=p^{C}_{ij}+\mathcal{O}(\hbar)\;. (4)

Furthermore, if the supports of fisubscript𝑓𝑖f_{i} and fjsubscript𝑓𝑗f_{j} are disjoint, pi​j,ℏQ=𝒪​(ℏ∞)subscriptsuperscript𝑝𝑄𝑖𝑗Planck-constant-over-2-pi𝒪superscriptPlanck-constant-over-2-pip^{Q}_{ij,\hbar}=\mathcal{O}(\hbar^{\infty}).

The proof is given in Section 5.

3 Topological analysis of registration data

Fix a Riemannian metric on the phase space M𝑀M. Denote by d𝑑d the corresponding distance function and by B​(z,r)𝐵𝑧𝑟B(z,r) the open metric ball of radius r𝑟r centered in z∈M𝑧𝑀z\in M. Take r′>0superscript𝑟′0r^{\prime}>0 such that every ball of radius 4​r′4superscript𝑟′4r^{\prime} in M𝑀M is a convex normal neighbourhood of its center (that is each two of its points can be connected by the unique globally minimal geodesics which is fully contained in the ball).

The role of a sensor network mentioned in the introduction will be played by a finite subset Z⊂M𝑍𝑀Z\subset M. We assume that Z𝑍Z is an r/2𝑟2r/2-net in M𝑀M, r>0𝑟0r>0, that is the balls B​(z,r/2)𝐵𝑧𝑟2B(z,r/2), z∈Z𝑧𝑍z\in Z cover M𝑀M. Furthermore we fix a constant λ>1𝜆1\lambda>1 and assume that

r′/r>4​λ4.superscript𝑟′𝑟4superscript𝜆4r^{\prime}/r>4\lambda^{4}\;. (5)

Consider the cover 𝒰ϵsubscript𝒰italic-ϵ{\mathcal{U}}_{\epsilon} of M𝑀M by the balls of radii λ​ϵ/2𝜆italic-ϵ2\lambda\epsilon/2 centered in the points of Z𝑍Z, where

ϵ∈ℐ:=[2​r​λ;2​r′/λ].italic-ϵℐassign2𝑟𝜆2superscript𝑟′𝜆\epsilon\in{\mathcal{I}}:=[2r\lambda;2r^{\prime}/\lambda]\;.

Take any partition of unity {fz(ϵ)}subscriptsuperscript𝑓italic-ϵ𝑧\{f^{(\epsilon)}_{z}\}, z∈Z𝑧𝑍z\in Z, subordinated to 𝒰ϵsubscript𝒰italic-ϵ{\mathcal{U}}_{\epsilon} with the following property:

Assumption ♠♠\spadesuit: For every z∈Z𝑧𝑍z\in Z and ϵ∈ℐitalic-ϵℐ\epsilon\in{\mathcal{I}}

B​(z,ϵ/(2​λ))⊂Interior​(𝑠𝑢𝑝𝑝​fz(ϵ))⊂𝑠𝑢𝑝𝑝​fz(ϵ)⊂B​(z,λ​ϵ/2).𝐵𝑧italic-ϵ2𝜆Interior𝑠𝑢𝑝𝑝subscriptsuperscript𝑓italic-ϵ𝑧𝑠𝑢𝑝𝑝subscriptsuperscript𝑓italic-ϵ𝑧𝐵𝑧𝜆italic-ϵ2B(z,\epsilon/(2\lambda))\subset\text{Interior}({\it supp\,}f^{(\epsilon)}_{z})\subset{\it supp\,}f^{(\epsilon)}_{z}\subset B(z,\lambda\epsilon/2)\;.

Assumption ♣♣\clubsuit: For every z∈Z𝑧𝑍z\in Z,

𝑠𝑢𝑝𝑝​fz(ϵ1)⊂𝑠𝑢𝑝𝑝​fz(ϵ2)​for​ϵ1,ϵ2∈ℐ,ϵ1<ϵ2.formulae-sequence𝑠𝑢𝑝𝑝subscriptsuperscript𝑓subscriptitalic-ϵ1𝑧𝑠𝑢𝑝𝑝subscriptsuperscript𝑓subscriptitalic-ϵ2𝑧forsubscriptitalic-ϵ1formulae-sequencesubscriptitalic-ϵ2ℐsubscriptitalic-ϵ1subscriptitalic-ϵ2{\it supp\,}f^{(\epsilon_{1})}_{z}\subset{\it supp\,}f^{(\epsilon_{2})}_{z}\;\;\text{for}\;\;\epsilon_{1},\epsilon_{2}\in{\mathcal{I}},\;\epsilon_{1}<\epsilon_{2}\;. (6)

Finally, pick a,b∈ℐ0𝑎𝑏superscriptℐ0a,b\in{\mathcal{I}}^{0} (where ℐ0superscriptℐ0{\mathcal{I}}^{0} stands for the interior of ℐℐ{\mathcal{I}}) with

Assumption ♢♢\diamondsuit: For every s∈{a,b}𝑠𝑎𝑏s\in\{a,b\} and z,w∈Z𝑧𝑤𝑍z,w\in Z, if the interiors of the supports of fz(s)subscriptsuperscript𝑓𝑠𝑧f^{(s)}_{z} and fw(s)subscriptsuperscript𝑓𝑠𝑤f^{(s)}_{w} do not intersect, then the supports do not intersect.

For instance, if the boundaries of the support of fz(s)subscriptsuperscript𝑓𝑠𝑧f^{(s)}_{z} are generic smooth s𝑠s-dependent families of embedded hypersurfaces, assumption (♢♢\diamondsuit) holds true for all but finite number of values of the parameter s𝑠s. Thus this assumption can be achieved by a small perturbation of any pair a,b𝑎𝑏a,b satisfying (7).

Example 3.1.

Assume, for instance, that for every z∈Z𝑧𝑍z\in Z and s∈ℐ𝑠ℐs\in{\mathcal{I}}, the support of fz(s)subscriptsuperscript𝑓𝑠𝑧f^{(s)}_{z} equals the closure of B​(z,s)𝐵𝑧𝑠B(z,s). Then (♢♢\diamondsuit) fails only for s𝑠s taking value in a finite set

Convention ♡♡\heartsuit: We fix m>0𝑚0m>0, and a𝑎a and b𝑏b from ℐ0superscriptℐ0{\mathcal{I}}^{0} satisfying (7). If m≥1𝑚1m\geq 1, we assume in addition that a,b𝑎𝑏a,b satisfy (♢♢\diamondsuit) aaaWe thank Laurent Charles for noticing that assumption (♢♢\diamondsuit) is not needed when m<1𝑚1m<1.

As in the previous section, for every ϵ∈ℐitalic-ϵℐ\epsilon\in{\mathcal{I}} consider the quantum repeated registration procedure with respect to the sensor network Z𝑍Z and the partition of unity {fz(ϵ)}subscriptsuperscript𝑓italic-ϵ𝑧\{f^{(\epsilon)}_{z}\}, and write pz​w,ℏ,ϵQsubscriptsuperscript𝑝𝑄𝑧𝑤Planck-constant-over-2-piitalic-ϵp^{Q}_{zw,\hbar,\epsilon} for the probabilities of the outcome z,w𝑧𝑤z,w. Here we bookkeep the dependence on ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon in our notation. Form the complex Qm,ℏ,ϵsubscript𝑄𝑚Planck-constant-over-2-piitalic-ϵQ_{m,\hbar,\epsilon} as follows. Proposition 3.2.

Qm,ℏ,a⊂Qm,ℏ,bsubscript𝑄𝑚Planck-constant-over-2-pi𝑎subscript𝑄𝑚Planck-constant-over-2-pi𝑏Q_{m,\hbar,a}\subset Q_{m,\hbar,b} for all sufficiently small ℏPlanck-constant-over-2-pi\hbar.

For a sufficiently small ℏPlanck-constant-over-2-pi\hbar define a vector space Xm,ℏ,a,bsubscript𝑋𝑚Planck-constant-over-2-pi𝑎𝑏X_{m,\hbar,a,b} as the image of the natural morphism

H​(Qm,ℏ,a)→H​(Qm,ℏ,b)→𝐻subscript𝑄𝑚Planck-constant-over-2-pi𝑎𝐻subscript𝑄𝑚Planck-constant-over-2-pi𝑏H(Q_{m,\hbar,a})\to H(Q_{m,\hbar,b})

in homology. Here and below we use homology with coefficients in a field. Now we are ready to formulate our main result under assumptions (♠♠\spadesuit), (♣♣\clubsuit) and convention (♡♡\heartsuit).

Theorem 3.3.

The space Xm,ℏ,a,bsubscript𝑋𝑚Planck-constant-over-2-pi𝑎𝑏X_{m,\hbar,a,b} is isomorphic to the homology of the phase space H​(M)𝐻𝑀H(M) for every sufficiently small ℏ>0Planck-constant-over-2-pi0\hbar>0.

The proof of Proposition 3.2 and Theorem 3.3 occupies the next section.

4 Persistent homology: proofs

We shall proof Theorem 3.3 in three steps: first, we compare the complex Qm,ℏ,ϵsubscript𝑄𝑚Planck-constant-over-2-piitalic-ϵQ_{m,\hbar,\epsilon} with its classical analogue, next we observe that the latter is in some sense close to the Vietoris-Rips complex of the sensor network Z𝑍Z, and finally we deduce the theorem by using methods of topological data analysis.

4.1 The classical complex

For every ϵ∈ℐitalic-ϵℐ\epsilon\in{\mathcal{I}} consider the classical repeated registration procedure with respect to the sensor network Z𝑍Z and the partition of unity {fz(ϵ)}subscriptsuperscript𝑓italic-ϵ𝑧\{f^{(\epsilon)}_{z}\}, and write pz​w,ϵCsubscriptsuperscript𝑝𝐶𝑧𝑤italic-ϵp^{C}_{zw,\epsilon} for the probabilities of the outcome z,w𝑧𝑤z,w. Form the complex Cϵsubscript𝐶italic-ϵC_{\epsilon} as follows. Its vertices are the points of Z𝑍Z, and the subset σ⊂Z𝜎𝑍\sigma\subset Z forms a simplex of Cϵsubscript𝐶italic-ϵC_{\epsilon} whenever pz​w,ϵC>0superscriptsubscript𝑝𝑧𝑤italic-ϵ𝐶0p_{zw,\epsilon}^{C}>0 for all z,w∈σ𝑧𝑤𝜎z,w\in\sigma with z≠w𝑧𝑤z\neq w.

Proposition 4.1.

For fixed m,ϵ𝑚italic-ϵm,\epsilon and a sufficiently small ℏPlanck-constant-over-2-pi\hbar

Cϵ=Qm,ℏ,ϵsubscript𝐶italic-ϵsubscript𝑄𝑚Planck-constant-over-2-piitalic-ϵC_{\epsilon}=Q_{m,\hbar,\epsilon}\; (8)

provided ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon satisfies (♢♢\diamondsuit).

Proof.

For ϵ∈ℐitalic-ϵℐ\epsilon\in{\mathcal{I}} put

γϵ=min⁡{pz​w,ϵC:z,w∈Z,z≠w,pz​w,ϵC>0}.subscript𝛾italic-ϵ:superscriptsubscript𝑝𝑧𝑤italic-ϵ𝐶𝑧𝑤𝑍𝑧𝑤superscriptsubscript𝑝𝑧𝑤italic-ϵ𝐶0\gamma_{\epsilon}=\min\{p_{zw,\epsilon}^{C}\;:\;z,w\in Z,z\neq w,p_{zw,\epsilon}^{C}>0\}\;. (9)

Note that γϵ>0subscript𝛾italic-ϵ0\gamma_{\epsilon}>0. Applying formula (4) in Proposition 2.1 we see that

If m<1𝑚1m<1, formula (4) in Proposition 2.1 implies that

In both cases we get that Cϵ⊃Qm,ℏ,ϵsubscript𝑄𝑚Planck-constant-over-2-piitalic-ϵsubscript𝐶italic-ϵC_{\epsilon}\supset Q_{m,\hbar,\epsilon}, which completes the proof. ∎

In particular, for all sufficiently small ℏPlanck-constant-over-2-pi\hbar

Qm,ℏ,a=Ca​and​Qm,ℏ,b=Cb,subscript𝑄𝑚Planck-constant-over-2-pi𝑎subscript𝐶𝑎andsubscript𝑄𝑚Planck-constant-over-2-pi𝑏subscript𝐶𝑏Q_{m,\hbar,a}=C_{a}\;\;\text{and}\;\;Q_{m,\hbar,b}=C_{b}\;, (10)

4.2 Persistence modules and their barcodes

Next, we focus on the family of complexes Ctsubscript𝐶𝑡C_{t}, t∈ℐ𝑡ℐt\in{\mathcal{I}}. Note that assumption (♣♣\clubsuit) guarantees that Ct⊂Cssubscript𝐶𝑡subscript𝐶𝑠C_{t}\subset C_{s} for s<t𝑠𝑡s<t and hence Cssubscript𝐶𝑠C_{s} is a filtered complex. Combining this with (10), we deduce Proposition 3.2.

We shall study the filtered complex {Cs}subscript𝐶𝑠\{C_{s}\} by using techniques of persistence modules, see [12, 10, 19] for an introduction.bbbWarning: Here and below we work with persistence modules parameterized by positive real numbers ℝ+subscriptℝ{\mathbb{R}}_{+}. The group ℝ+subscriptℝ{\mathbb{R}}_{+} acts by multiplication on the set of parameters. The notion of interleaving and the stability theorem are adjusted accordingly. Let us recall some preliminaries. A point-wise finite dimensional persistence module is a family of finite-dimensional vector spaces Vasubscript𝑉𝑎V_{a}, a∈ℝ+𝑎subscriptℝa\in{\mathbb{R}}_{+} over a field ℱℱ{\mathcal{F}} together with persistence morphisms πa​bV:Va→Vb:subscriptsuperscript𝜋𝑉𝑎𝑏→subscript𝑉𝑎subscript𝑉𝑏\pi^{V}_{ab}:V_{a}\to V_{b}, a<b𝑎𝑏a<b, such that πb​cV∘πa​bV=πa​cVsubscriptsuperscript𝜋𝑉𝑏𝑐subscriptsuperscript𝜋𝑉𝑎𝑏subscriptsuperscript𝜋𝑉𝑎𝑐\pi^{V}_{bc}\circ\pi^{V}_{ab}=\pi^{V}_{ac} provided a<b<c𝑎𝑏𝑐a<b<c. An important example is given by an interval module ℱ​(I)ℱ𝐼{\mathcal{F}}(I), where I𝐼I is an interval (that is, a connected subset) of ℝ+subscriptℝ{\mathbb{R}}_{+} which is defined as ℱ​(I)a=ℱℱsubscript𝐼𝑎ℱ{\mathcal{F}}(I)_{a}={\mathcal{F}} for a∈I𝑎𝐼a\in I and 00 otherwise, and πa​bℱ​(I)=1​lsubscriptsuperscript𝜋ℱ𝐼𝑎𝑏1l\pi^{{\mathcal{F}}(I)}_{ab}={1\hskip-2.5pt{\rm l}} for a,b∈I𝑎𝑏𝐼a,b\in I and 00 otherwise. According to the normal form theorem, for every persistence module V𝑉V there exists unique collection of intervals with multiplicities, which is called a barcode and denoted by ℬ​(V)ℬ𝑉{\mathcal{B}}(V), so that V=⊕I∈ℬ​(V)ℱ​(I)𝑉subscriptdirect-sum𝐼ℬ𝑉ℱ𝐼V=\oplus_{I\in{\mathcal{B}}(V)}{\mathcal{F}}(I).

The following notion (see [10]) is crucial for our purposes. Two persistence modules V𝑉V and W𝑊W are called K𝐾K-interleaved (K>1𝐾1K>1) if there exist linear maps ϕa:Va→WK​a:subscriptitalic-ϕ𝑎→subscript𝑉𝑎subscript𝑊𝐾𝑎\phi_{a}:V_{a}\to W_{Ka} and ψa:Wa→VK​a:subscript𝜓𝑎→subscript𝑊𝑎subscript𝑉𝐾𝑎\psi_{a}:W_{a}\to V_{Ka} commuting with the respective persistence morphisms so that

ϕa∘ψa/K=πa/K,K​aW,ψa∘ϕa/K=πa/K,K​aV​∀a∈ℝ+.formulae-sequencesubscriptitalic-ϕ𝑎subscript𝜓𝑎𝐾subscriptsuperscript𝜋𝑊𝑎𝐾𝐾𝑎subscript𝜓𝑎subscriptitalic-ϕ𝑎𝐾subscriptsuperscript𝜋𝑉𝑎𝐾𝐾𝑎for-all𝑎subscriptℝ\phi_{a}\circ\psi_{a/K}=\pi^{W}_{a/K,Ka},\;\;\psi_{a}\circ\phi_{a/K}=\pi^{V}_{a/K,Ka}\;\;\forall a\in{\mathbb{R}}_{+}\;.

According to a deep stability theorem, one can erase certain (not necessarily all) bars in ℬ​(V)ℬ𝑉{\mathcal{B}}(V) and ℬ​(W)ℬ𝑊{\mathcal{B}}(W) with the ratio of the endpoints ≤K2absentsuperscript𝐾2\leq K^{2} such that the rest of the bars are matched in one to one manner as follows: if a bar I∈ℬ​(V)𝐼ℬ𝑉I\in{\mathcal{B}}(V) with endpoints a<b𝑎𝑏a<b corresponds to a bar J∈ℬ​(W)𝐽ℬ𝑊J\in{\mathcal{B}}(W) with endpoints a′<b′superscript𝑎′superscript𝑏′a^{\prime}<b^{\prime} then

K−1≤a/a′≤K,K−1≤b/b′≤K.formulae-sequencesuperscript𝐾1𝑎superscript𝑎′𝐾superscript𝐾1𝑏superscript𝑏′𝐾K^{-1}\leq a/a^{\prime}\leq K,\;K^{-1}\leq b/b^{\prime}\leq K\;.

For a persistence module V𝑉V, define the subspace

Ps​t​(V):=Image​(πs​tV),s<t.formulae-sequenceassignsubscript𝑃𝑠𝑡𝑉Imagesuperscriptsubscript𝜋𝑠𝑡𝑉𝑠𝑡P_{st}(V):=\text{Image}(\pi_{st}^{V})\;,\;s<t\;.

Suppose that we are given a family of finite simplicial complexes Dssubscript𝐷𝑠D_{s}, with s𝑠s running over an interval 𝒥⊂ℝ+𝒥subscriptℝ{\mathcal{J}}\subset{\mathbb{R}}_{+} and Ds⊂Dtsubscript𝐷𝑠subscript𝐷𝑡D_{s}\subset D_{t} for s<t𝑠𝑡s<t. Consider a persistence module V𝑉V which equals H​(Ds)𝐻subscript𝐷𝑠H(D_{s}) for s∈𝒥𝑠𝒥s\in{\mathcal{J}} and vanishes outside 𝒥𝒥{\mathcal{J}} (for the idea of such a truncation, see e.g. [10]). By definition, the persistence morphisms πs​tVsubscriptsuperscript𝜋𝑉𝑠𝑡\pi^{V}_{st} are the inclusion morphisms in homology for s,t∈𝒥𝑠𝑡𝒥s,t\in{\mathcal{J}} and they vanish otherwise. For s,t∈𝒥𝑠𝑡𝒥s,t\in{\mathcal{J}}, s<t𝑠𝑡s<t the space Ps​t​(V)subscript𝑃𝑠𝑡𝑉P_{st}(V) is called the persistent homology of D𝐷D. We shall denote V=H¯​(D)𝒥𝑉¯𝐻subscript𝐷𝒥V=\overline{H}(D)_{{\mathcal{J}}}.

Apply the above construction to the family of classical complexes Cssubscript𝐶𝑠C_{s}, s∈ℐ𝑠ℐs\in{\mathcal{I}}. In light of Proposition 4.1,

Pa​b​(V)=Xm,ℏ,a,b,subscript𝑃𝑎𝑏𝑉subscript𝑋𝑚Planck-constant-over-2-pi𝑎𝑏P_{ab}(V)=X_{m,\hbar,a,b}\;, (11)

where the latter space is taken from Theorem 3.3 and V:=H¯​(C)ℐassign𝑉¯𝐻subscript𝐶ℐV:=\overline{H}(C)_{\mathcal{I}}.

4.3 Interleaving with the Vietoris-Rips complex

Recall [12, 19] that the Vietoris-Rips complex Rtsubscript𝑅𝑡R_{t}, t>0𝑡0t>0 of the subset Z⊂(M,d)𝑍𝑀𝑑Z\subset(M,d) playing the role of our sensor network is defined as the complex whose vertices are the points of Z𝑍Z, and a subset σ⊂Z𝜎𝑍\sigma\subset Z forms a simplex of Rtsubscript𝑅𝑡R_{t} whenever the diameter of σ𝜎\sigma is <tabsent𝑡<t. Apply the truncation construction to Rtsubscript𝑅𝑡R_{t}, t∈𝒥:=[2​r,2​r′]𝑡𝒥assign2𝑟2superscript𝑟′t\in{\mathcal{J}}:=[2r,2r^{\prime}] and get the persistence module W:=H¯​(R)𝒥assign𝑊¯𝐻subscript𝑅𝒥W:=\overline{H}(R)_{\mathcal{J}}. We keep notation V𝑉V for H¯​(C)ℐ¯𝐻subscript𝐶ℐ\overline{H}(C)_{\mathcal{I}}.

Proposition 4.2.

The persistence modules V𝑉V and W𝑊W are λ𝜆\lambda-interleaved.

Proof.

We employ assumption (♠♠\spadesuit). For s∈[2​r,2​r′/λ2]𝑠2𝑟2superscript𝑟′superscript𝜆2s\in[2r,2r^{\prime}/\lambda^{2}] and z,w∈Z𝑧𝑤𝑍z,w\in Z

so Rs⊂Cλ​ssubscript𝑅𝑠subscript𝐶𝜆𝑠R_{s}\subset C_{\lambda s}. Furthermore, for t∈[2​r​λ,2​r′/λ]𝑡2𝑟𝜆2superscript𝑟′𝜆t\in[2r\lambda,2r^{\prime}/\lambda]

Define the morphisms ϕs:Ws→Vλ​s:subscriptitalic-ϕ𝑠→subscript𝑊𝑠subscript𝑉𝜆𝑠\phi_{s}:W_{s}\to V_{\lambda s} and ψt:Vt→Wλ​t:subscript𝜓𝑡→subscript𝑉𝑡subscript𝑊𝜆𝑡\psi_{t}:V_{t}\to W_{\lambda t} as the inclusion morphisms in homology when s∈[2​r,2​r′/λ2]𝑠2𝑟2superscript𝑟′superscript𝜆2s\in[2r,2r^{\prime}/\lambda^{2}] and, respectively, t∈[2​r​λ,2​r′/λ]𝑡2𝑟𝜆2superscript𝑟′𝜆t\in[2r\lambda,2r^{\prime}/\lambda], and as 00 otherwise. A direct inspection shows that they provide a desired λ𝜆\lambda-interleaving. ∎

Proof of Theorem 3.3: We keep using notations V,W𝑉𝑊V,W as above. A standard comparison between the Vietoris-Rips and the Čech complexes [19] shows that the persistence module W𝑊W is 222-interleaved with a module Y𝑌Y such that Yt=H​(M)subscript𝑌𝑡𝐻𝑀Y_{t}=H(M) for t∈(r,4​r′)𝑡𝑟4superscript𝑟′t\in(r,4r^{\prime}) and Yt=0subscript𝑌𝑡0Y_{t}=0 otherwise. It follows from Proposition 4.2 that V𝑉V and Y𝑌Y are 2​λ2𝜆2\lambda-interleaved. Apply now the stability theorem. To any bar of ℬ​(V)ℬ𝑉{\mathcal{B}}(V) containing [a,b]𝑎𝑏[a,b], where a,b∈(2​r​λ,2​r′/λ)𝑎𝑏2𝑟𝜆2superscript𝑟′𝜆a,b\in(2r\lambda,2r^{\prime}/\lambda) and b/a>4​λ2𝑏𝑎4superscript𝜆2b/a>4\lambda^{2}, corresponds unique bar of ℬ​(Y)ℬ𝑌{\mathcal{B}}(Y). On the other hand, ℬ​(Y)ℬ𝑌{\mathcal{B}}(Y) has exactly dimH​(M)dimension𝐻𝑀\dim H(M) bars of the form (r,4​r′)𝑟4superscript𝑟′(r,4r^{\prime}), and therefore to each such bar corresponds a bar of ℬ​(V)ℬ𝑉{\mathcal{B}}(V) containing (2​r​λ,2​r′/λ)2𝑟𝜆2superscript𝑟′𝜆(2r\lambda,2r^{\prime}/\lambda), and hence containing [a,b]𝑎𝑏[a,b]. It follows that ℬ​(V)ℬ𝑉{\mathcal{B}}(V) possesses exactly dimH​(M)dimension𝐻𝑀\dim H(M) bars containing [a,b]𝑎𝑏[a,b] which yields Pa​b​(V)=H​(M)subscript𝑃𝑎𝑏𝑉𝐻𝑀P_{ab}(V)=H(M). Applying (11), we finish off the proof of the theorem. ∎

4.4 Discussion: do we really need barcodes?

Denote by Γ⊂ℝ+Γsubscriptℝ\Gamma\subset{\mathbb{R}}_{+} the finite set of all distances d​(z,w)𝑑𝑧𝑤d(z,w), where z,w∈Z𝑧𝑤𝑍z,w\in Z, z≠w𝑧𝑤z\neq w. Take any connected component of ℝ+∖ΓsubscriptℝΓ{\mathbb{R}}_{+}\setminus\Gamma which is bounded away from 00 and ∞\infty, and consider its intersection, say ΔΔ\Delta with 𝒥=[2​r,2​r′]𝒥2𝑟2superscript𝑟′{\mathcal{J}}=[2r,2r^{\prime}]. Observe that the Vietoris-Rips complex Rtsubscript𝑅𝑡R_{t} does not change when t𝑡t runs within ΔΔ\Delta. Take such a t𝑡t, and assume that the parameter λ>1𝜆1\lambda>1 is close to 111 so that

(t/λ,λ​t)⊂Δ.𝑡𝜆𝜆𝑡Δ(t/\lambda,\lambda t)\subset\Delta\;. (12)

Recall that λ𝜆\lambda appears in assumption (♠♠\spadesuit) on supports of functions fz(t)subscriptsuperscript𝑓𝑡𝑧f^{(t)}_{z}, z∈Z𝑧𝑍z\in Z from the partitions of unity; these functions play the role of probabilities in our registration model. Roughly speaking, λ𝜆\lambda measures deviation of the support from the metric ball B​(z,t)𝐵𝑧𝑡B(z,t). The proof of Proposition 4.2 together with inclusion (12) yield

Rt/λ⊂Ct⊂Rt​λ,subscript𝑅𝑡𝜆subscript𝐶𝑡subscript𝑅𝑡𝜆R_{t/\lambda}\subset C_{t}\subset R_{t\lambda}\;, (13)

and hence, since Rt/λ=Rt=Rt​λsubscript𝑅𝑡𝜆subscript𝑅𝑡subscript𝑅𝑡𝜆R_{t/\lambda}=R_{t}=R_{t\lambda}, we conclude that Ct=Rtsubscript𝐶𝑡subscript𝑅𝑡C_{t}=R_{t}.

Sometimes, for an individual value of the parameter, the Rips complex associated to a finite subset carries important topological information about the ambient manifold. For instance, by a theorem of Latschev [13], for every sufficiently small t>0𝑡0t>0 there exists r>0𝑟0r>0 such that Rtsubscript𝑅𝑡R_{t} is homotopically equivalent to M𝑀M for every r𝑟r-net Z𝑍Z in M𝑀M. Take such t𝑡t, and choose r>0𝑟0r>0 small enough so that t∈𝒥𝑡𝒥t\in{\mathcal{J}} and Latschev’s theorem holds. Choosing Z𝑍Z to be a generic r/2𝑟2r/2-net, we can achieve that t∉Γ𝑡Γt\notin\Gamma. Next, pick λ>1𝜆1\lambda>1 so close to 111 that Ct=Rtsubscript𝐶𝑡subscript𝑅𝑡C_{t}=R_{t}. Finally, assume that (♢♢\diamondsuit) holds for t𝑡t, which, for instance, holds when the boundaries of the supports of the functions fz(t)subscriptsuperscript𝑓𝑡𝑧f^{(t)}_{z} are smooth and intersect transversally. Then (11) guarantees that for a given m𝑚m and a sufficiently small ℏPlanck-constant-over-2-pi\hbar we have Qm,ℏ,t=Ctsubscript𝑄𝑚Planck-constant-over-2-pi𝑡subscript𝐶𝑡Q_{m,\hbar,t}=C_{t}. This yields that, for specially chosen sensor nets Z𝑍Z and for λ𝜆\lambda sufficiently close to 111, the quantum complex Qm,ℏ,tsubscript𝑄𝑚Planck-constant-over-2-pi𝑡Q_{m,\hbar,t} has the homotopy type of M𝑀M. Let us mention that in this case we got a stronger conclusion without applying the stability theorem for persistence modules which plays a crucial role in our proof of Theorem 3.3.

However, for the values of λ𝜆\lambda which are large in comparison with the ratios of the consecutive points in ΓΓ\Gamma, the above argument fails since “sandwiching” (13) does not allow one to detect topology of the classical complex C𝐶C in terms of the Vietoris-Rips complex R𝑅R. At this point the stability theorem enters the play, and we do not see a shortcut.

5 Registration: proofs

Derivation of formula (1): Preparation of a system in the classical state ν𝜈\nu means choosing an M𝑀M-valued random variable Z𝑍Z which is uniformly distributed with respect to ν𝜈\nu, i.e., the probability of finding Z𝑍Z in a subset U⊂M𝑈𝑀U\subset M equals ν​(U)𝜈𝑈\nu(U). Let R𝑅R be another random variable (registration) taking values in {1,…,N}1…𝑁\{1,...,N\} and defined on the same space of elementary events as Z𝑍Z. By definition, fi​(z)subscript𝑓𝑖𝑧f_{i}(z) is the conditional probability ℙ​(R=i|Z=z)ℙ𝑅conditional𝑖𝑍𝑧{\mathbb{P}}(R=i|Z=z), which in turn means (again, by definition; remember that Z𝑍Z is in general a continuous random variable) that for every U⊂M𝑈𝑀U\subset M the joint probability ℙ​(R=i,Z∈U)ℙformulae-sequence𝑅𝑖𝑍𝑈{\mathbb{P}}(R=i,Z\in U) is given by

ℙ​(R=i,Z∈U)=∫Uℙ​(R=i|Z=z)​𝑑ν​(z).ℙformulae-sequence𝑅𝑖𝑍𝑈subscript𝑈ℙ𝑅conditional𝑖𝑍𝑧differential-d𝜈𝑧{\mathbb{P}}(R=i,Z\in U)=\int_{U}{\mathbb{P}}(R=i|Z=z)d\nu(z)\;.

Substituting U=M𝑈𝑀U=M and having in mind that piC:=ℙ​(R=i)assignsubscriptsuperscript𝑝𝐶𝑖ℙ𝑅𝑖p^{C}_{i}:={\mathbb{P}}(R=i) we get (1). ∎

Derivation of formula (3): We assume that the first and the second registrations, denoted by R1subscript𝑅1R_{1} and R2subscript𝑅2R_{2} respectively, are random variables defined on the same space of elementary events as Z𝑍Z, which are conditionally independent given Z𝑍Z: ℙ​(R1=i,R2=j|Z=z)=fi​(z)​fj​(z)ℙformulae-sequencesubscript𝑅1𝑖subscript𝑅2conditional𝑗𝑍𝑧subscript𝑓𝑖𝑧subscript𝑓𝑗𝑧{\mathbb{P}}(R_{1}=i,R_{2}=j|Z=z)=f_{i}(z)f_{j}(z). It follows that

pi​jC=ℙ​(R1=i,R2=j)=∫Mfi​fj​𝑑μ,subscriptsuperscript𝑝𝐶𝑖𝑗ℙformulae-sequencesubscript𝑅1𝑖subscript𝑅2𝑗subscript𝑀subscript𝑓𝑖subscript𝑓𝑗differential-d𝜇p^{C}_{ij}={\mathbb{P}}(R_{1}=i,R_{2}=j)=\int_{M}f_{i}f_{j}d\mu\;,

which proves (3). ∎

This is an immediate consequence of the exponential decay of the scalar product between distinct coherent states as ℏ→0→Planck-constant-over-2-pi0\hbar\to 0, see [4, 9]. ∎

6 Inferring the nerve of a cover

Let (M,μ)𝑀𝜇(M,\mu) be a probability space endowed with a finite cover 𝒰={U1,…,UN}𝒰subscript𝑈1…subscript𝑈𝑁{\mathcal{U}}=\{U_{1},\dots,U_{N}\} by measurable subsets. The measure μ𝜇\mu represents the initial distribution of a particle in M𝑀M. In this section we deal with a version of the registration procedure involving a special partition of unity of the following form. Denote by χisubscript𝜒𝑖\chi_{i} the indicator function of Uisubscript𝑈𝑖U_{i}, and put χ:=∑kχkassign𝜒subscript𝑘subscript𝜒𝑘\chi:=\sum_{k}\chi_{k}, fi:=χi/χassignsubscript𝑓𝑖subscript𝜒𝑖𝜒f_{i}:=\chi_{i}/\chi. The functions fisubscript𝑓𝑖f_{i} vanish outside Uisubscript𝑈𝑖U_{i} and form a partition of unity. For a vector I:=(i1,…,ik)assign𝐼subscript𝑖1…subscript𝑖𝑘I:=(i_{1},\dots,i_{k}) with ij∈ΩN:={1,…,N}subscript𝑖𝑗subscriptΩ𝑁assign1…𝑁i_{j}\in\Omega_{N}:=\{1,\dots,N\} put UI:=Ui1∩⋯∩Uikassignsubscript𝑈𝐼subscript𝑈subscript𝑖1⋯subscript𝑈subscript𝑖𝑘U_{I}:=U_{i_{1}}\cap\dots\cap U_{i_{k}}. The probability of k𝑘k-times repeated registration in sets Ui1,…,Uiksubscript𝑈subscript𝑖1…subscript𝑈subscript𝑖𝑘U_{i_{1}},\dots,U_{i_{k}} equals by definition

pIC:=∫Mfi1​…​fik​𝑑μ=∫UIχ−k​(z)​𝑑μ​(z).assignsubscriptsuperscript𝑝𝐶𝐼subscript𝑀subscript𝑓subscript𝑖1…subscript𝑓subscript𝑖𝑘differential-d𝜇subscriptsubscript𝑈𝐼superscript𝜒𝑘𝑧differential-d𝜇𝑧p^{C}_{I}:=\int_{M}f_{i_{1}}\dots f_{i_{k}}d\mu=\int_{U_{I}}\chi^{-k}(z)d\mu(z)\;. (16)
Example 6.1.

Consider a toy case when M𝑀M is a finite set. A cover 𝒰𝒰{\mathcal{U}} can be considered as a hypergraph with the set of vertices M𝑀M and with edges Uisubscript𝑈𝑖U_{i}, i=1,…,N𝑖1…𝑁i=1,...,N. Introduce a probability measure μ𝜇\mu on M𝑀M as follows:

μ​(z)=χ​(z)/S,where​S:=∑z∈Mχ​(z).formulae-sequence𝜇𝑧𝜒𝑧𝑆assignwhere𝑆subscript𝑧𝑀𝜒𝑧\mu(z)=\chi(z)/S,\;\;\text{where}\;\;S:=\sum_{z\in M}\chi(z)\;.

In other words the probability of a vertex is proportional to the number of edges containing it. Consider two-times repeated registration and look at the conditional probability ℙ​(j|i)ℙconditional𝑗𝑖\mathbb{P}(j|i), where i,j∈ΩN𝑖𝑗subscriptΩ𝑁i,j\in\Omega_{N}, of getting j𝑗j as the second outcome provided the first one equals i𝑖i. Note that ℙ​(j|i)=pi​jC/piCℙconditional𝑗𝑖superscriptsubscript𝑝𝑖𝑗𝐶superscriptsubscript𝑝𝑖𝐶\mathbb{P}(j|i)=p_{ij}^{C}/p_{i}^{C}, where by (16),

piC=♯​(Ui)/S,pi​jC=S−1⋅∑z∈Ui∩Ujχ−1​(z),formulae-sequencesuperscriptsubscript𝑝𝑖𝐶♯subscript𝑈𝑖𝑆superscriptsubscript𝑝𝑖𝑗𝐶⋅superscript𝑆1subscript𝑧subscript𝑈𝑖subscript𝑈𝑗superscript𝜒1𝑧p_{i}^{C}=\sharp(U_{i})/S,\;\;p_{ij}^{C}=S^{-1}\cdot\sum_{z\in U_{i}\cap U_{j}}\chi^{-1}(z)\;,

where ♯♯\sharp stands for the cardinality. It follows that

ℙ​(j|i)=∑z∈Ui∩Ujχ−1​(z)♯​(Ui),ℙconditional𝑗𝑖subscript𝑧subscript𝑈𝑖subscript𝑈𝑗superscript𝜒1𝑧♯subscript𝑈𝑖\mathbb{P}(j|i)=\frac{\sum_{z\in U_{i}\cap U_{j}}\chi^{-1}(z)}{\sharp(U_{i})}\;,

which, interestingly enough, coincides with the transition probability of the random walk on the edges of a hypergraph as defined in [1]. Warning: our model of k𝑘k-times repeated registration differs from this random walk at time k𝑘k when k≥3𝑘3k\geq 3 since our experimentalist registers all the way the same particle z∈M𝑧𝑀z\in M. Rather, the random walk models an “absent-minded experimentalist” which at each step book-keeps the outcome of the previous registration but loses track of the specific particle, and therefore chooses it at random within the subset corresponding to this outcome.

Suppose now that M𝑀M is a closed manifold equipped with a quantizable symplectic form ω𝜔\omega. Write μ𝜇\mu for the (normalized) symplectic volume. Let 𝒰𝒰{\mathcal{U}} be any finite cover of M𝑀M by open subsets with smooth boundaries.

Denote by ΘksubscriptΘ𝑘\Theta_{k}, k=1,…,N𝑘1…𝑁k=1,\dots,N, the set of vectors I=(i1,…,ik)⊂ΩNk𝐼subscript𝑖1…subscript𝑖𝑘superscriptsubscriptΩ𝑁𝑘I=(i_{1},\dots,i_{k})\subset\Omega_{N}^{k} with strictly increasing coordinates: i1<⋯<iksubscript𝑖1⋯subscript𝑖𝑘i_{1}<\dots<i_{k}. Such vectors are identified with subsets of ΩNsubscriptΩ𝑁\Omega_{N}. Recall that the nerve of the cover 𝒰𝒰{\mathcal{U}} is a simplicial complex L​(𝒰)𝐿𝒰L({\mathcal{U}}) with vertices ΩNsubscriptΩ𝑁\Omega_{N} whose k𝑘k-simplices are formed by vectors I∈Θk𝐼subscriptΘ𝑘I\in\Theta_{k} with UI≠∅subscript𝑈𝐼U_{I}\neq\emptyset. The latter condition holds if and only if pIC>0subscriptsuperscript𝑝𝐶𝐼0p^{C}_{I}>0. It follows that the repeated classical registration procedure detects the nerve of the cover. In particular, if the cover is good, i.e., all the sets 𝒰Isubscript𝒰𝐼{\mathcal{U}}_{I} for all values of k𝑘k are either empty or contractible, the nerve lemma guarantees that L​(𝒰)𝐿𝒰L({\mathcal{U}}) has the homotopy type of M𝑀M.

Consider now k𝑘k-times repeated quantum registration. Put Fi,ℏ=Tℏ​(fi)subscript𝐹𝑖Planck-constant-over-2-pisubscript𝑇Planck-constant-over-2-pisubscript𝑓𝑖F_{i,\hbar}=T_{\hbar}(f_{i}), where Tℏsubscript𝑇Planck-constant-over-2-piT_{\hbar} stands for the Berezin-Toeplitz quantization. A straightforward calculation involving the Lüders rule and the state reduction (cf. Section 5) shows that the probability pIQsubscriptsuperscript𝑝𝑄𝐼p^{Q}_{I} of k𝑘k-times repeated registration in I:=(i1,…,ik)assign𝐼subscript𝑖1…subscript𝑖𝑘I:=(i_{1},\dots,i_{k}) equals

pI,ℏQ:=trace​(Fik,ℏ1/2​…​Fi2,ℏ1/2​Fi1,ℏ​Fi2,ℏ1/2​…​Fik,ℏ1/2)dimℋℏ.assignsubscriptsuperscript𝑝𝑄𝐼Planck-constant-over-2-pitracesuperscriptsubscript𝐹subscript𝑖𝑘Planck-constant-over-2-pi12…superscriptsubscript𝐹subscript𝑖2Planck-constant-over-2-pi12subscript𝐹subscript𝑖1Planck-constant-over-2-pisuperscriptsubscript𝐹subscript𝑖2Planck-constant-over-2-pi12…superscriptsubscript𝐹subscript𝑖𝑘Planck-constant-over-2-pi12dimensionsubscriptℋPlanck-constant-over-2-pip^{Q}_{I,\hbar}:=\frac{{{\rm trace}}(F_{i_{k},\hbar}^{1/2}\dots F_{i_{2},\hbar}^{1/2}F_{i_{1},\hbar}F_{i_{2},\hbar}^{1/2}\dots F_{i_{k},\hbar}^{1/2})}{\dim\mathcal{H}_{\hbar}}\;. (17)
Theorem 6.2 (L. Charles).

pI,ℏQ=pIC+𝒪​(ℏ1/8)subscriptsuperscript𝑝𝑄𝐼Planck-constant-over-2-pisubscriptsuperscript𝑝𝐶𝐼𝒪superscriptPlanck-constant-over-2-pi18p^{Q}_{I,\hbar}=p^{C}_{I}+\mathcal{O}(\hbar^{1/8}).

The proof is given in the Appendix written by Laurent Charles. A delicate point in this theorem is that the functions fisubscript𝑓𝑖f_{i} are non-smooth, which makes the standard results on the quantum-classical correspondence nonapplicable in this case.

Fix now any m<1/8𝑚18m<1/8, and consider the simplicial complex with vertices {1,…,N}1…𝑁\{1,\dots,N\} such that the vector I∈Θk𝐼subscriptΘ𝑘I\in\Theta_{k} forms a simplex whenever pIQ>ℏmsubscriptsuperscript𝑝𝑄𝐼superscriptPlanck-constant-over-2-pi𝑚p^{Q}_{I}>\hbar^{m}. By Theorem 6.2, this complex coincides with the nerve L​(𝒰)𝐿𝒰L({\mathcal{U}}) for all sufficiently small ℏPlanck-constant-over-2-pi\hbar. Hence, for good covers, we inferred the homotopy type of the phase space.

7 Discussion and further directions

The subject of the present note is related to manifold learning, a technique of inferring topology of low-dimensional submanifolds of ℝnsuperscriptℝ𝑛{\mathbb{R}}^{n} from sufficiently dense samples (see e.g. [18]). The motivation comes from dimensionality reduction in data analysis. While closed symplectic manifolds (i.e., phase spaces) do not naturally arise as submanifolds of linear spaces, many interesting examples appear as the Marsden-Weinstein reduction of symplectic manifolds equipped with a Hamiltonian Lie group action [16]. It would be interesting to explore whether topology of a reduced phase space can be reconstructed from quantum data.

It is tempting to apply the technique of the present note to the tunneling effect discussed in the introduction. Assume that we are given a classical Hamiltonian g𝑔g on M𝑀M. Let ξℏsubscript𝜉Planck-constant-over-2-pi\xi_{\hbar} be a generic linear combination of pure eigenstates of the quantum Hamiltonian Tℏ​(g)subscript𝑇Planck-constant-over-2-pi𝑔T_{\hbar}(g) with the eigenvalues from a sufficiently small neighborhood of λ𝜆\lambda, where λ𝜆\lambda is a regular value of g𝑔g. Suppose that the initial state of the system equals ξℏsubscript𝜉Planck-constant-over-2-pi\xi_{\hbar}. Can one infer homology of the level set {g=λ}𝑔𝜆\{g=\lambda\} from the statistics of consecutive registrations with respect to a sufficiently dense system of sensors?

Another natural question is whether one can infer symplectic topology of quantum phase space. While reconstructing the symplectic structure seems to be out of reach, one can detect certain quantum footprints of symplectic rigidity, see e.g. [21].

Can one recover the homotopy type of the quantum phase space? In this note we did this for quite special partitions of unity, see Sections 4.4 and 6, while for more general partitions considered in Section 3 we restricted ourselves to a modest topological information such as homology with coefficients in a field. Detecting the homotopy type in this generality might be plausible, cf. [13, 18], but seemingly requires new ideas.

Let us mention, for the record, that for the standard Berezin-Toeplitz quantization of closed Kähler manifolds the dimension of the quantum Hilbert space ℋℏsubscriptℋPlanck-constant-over-2-pi\mathcal{H}_{\hbar} is given by the Hirzebruch-Riemann-Roch formula [15] which carries certain topological information. For instance, if M𝑀M is a closed real surface of genus g𝑔g equipped with a quantizable symplectic form,

dimℋℏ=Area​(M)2​π​ℏ+1−g.dimensionsubscriptℋPlanck-constant-over-2-piArea𝑀2𝜋Planck-constant-over-2-pi1𝑔\dim\mathcal{H}_{\hbar}=\frac{\text{Area}(M)}{2\pi\hbar}+1-g\;.

However, I am unable to come up with any gedankenexperiment which enables one to detect dimℋℏdimensionsubscriptℋPlanck-constant-over-2-pi\dim\mathcal{H}_{\hbar}.

Finally, an intriguing link between topological data analysis and quantum mechanics, which goes another way around, appears in [14]. In this paper, the authors propose a quantum algorithm for calculating persistent homology. It would be interesting to implement it for inferring topology of a quantum phase space along the lines of Section 3 above. This might shed some light on how topological structures arise in an intrinsic way in matrix quantum mechanics.

It was completed during my visits as a Mercator Fellow to Universität zu Köln and Ruhr-Universität Bochum in 2017. I am grateful to these institutions for their warm hospitality. I thank Shmuel Weinberger for useful discussions, as well as Laurent Charles, Yohann Le Floch, Vukašin Stojisavljević and Jun Zhang for helpful comments on the manuscript. My special thanks to Laurent Charles for encouraging me to add Section 6 and writing the Appendix.

Appendix A Toeplitz operators with piecewise constant symbol (by Laurent Charles)

In Berezin-Toeplitz quantization, we consider a symplectic compact manifold M𝑀M, a set Λ⊂ℝ>0Λsubscriptℝabsent0\Lambda\subset{\mathbb{R}}_{>0} having 00 as a limit point and for any ℏ∈ΛPlanck-constant-over-2-piΛ\hbar\in\Lambda, a Hermitian complex line bundle Lℏsubscript𝐿Planck-constant-over-2-piL_{\hbar} and a finite dimensional subspace ℋℏsubscriptℋPlanck-constant-over-2-pi\mathcal{H}_{\hbar} of 𝒞∞​(M,Lℏ)superscript𝒞𝑀subscript𝐿Planck-constant-over-2-pi{\mathcal{C}}^{\infty}(M,L_{\hbar}). The space ℋℏsubscriptℋPlanck-constant-over-2-pi\mathcal{H}_{\hbar} has a natural scalar product ⟨Ψ,Ψ′⟩ℋℏ=∫M(Ψ,Ψ′)​𝑑νsubscriptΨsuperscriptΨ′subscriptℋPlanck-constant-over-2-pisubscript𝑀ΨsuperscriptΨ′differential-d𝜈\langle\Psi,\Psi^{\prime}\rangle_{\mathcal{H}_{\hbar}}=\int_{M}(\Psi,\Psi^{\prime})\;d\nu where (Ψ,Ψ′)ΨsuperscriptΨ′(\Psi,\Psi^{\prime}) is the pointwise scalar product and ν𝜈\nu the Liouville measure cccthe Liouville measure of the previous sections is μ​(A)=ν​(A)/ν​(M)𝜇𝐴𝜈𝐴𝜈𝑀\mu(A)=\nu(A)/\nu(M) of M𝑀M. To any function f∈𝒞∞​(M)𝑓superscript𝒞𝑀f\in{\mathcal{C}}^{\infty}(M), we associate an endomorphism Tℏ​(f):ℋℏ→ℋℏ:subscript𝑇Planck-constant-over-2-pi𝑓→subscriptℋPlanck-constant-over-2-pisubscriptℋPlanck-constant-over-2-piT_{\hbar}(f):\mathcal{H}_{\hbar}\rightarrow\mathcal{H}_{\hbar} such that

⟨Tℏ​(f)​Ψ,Ψ′⟩ℋℏ=∫M(Ψ,Ψ′)​(x)​f​(x)​𝑑ν​(x),Ψ,Ψ′∈ℋℏ,formulae-sequencesubscriptsubscript𝑇Planck-constant-over-2-pi𝑓ΨsuperscriptΨ′subscriptℋPlanck-constant-over-2-pisubscript𝑀ΨsuperscriptΨ′𝑥𝑓𝑥differential-d𝜈𝑥ΨsuperscriptΨ′subscriptℋPlanck-constant-over-2-pi\displaystyle\langle T_{\hbar}(f)\Psi,\Psi^{\prime}\rangle_{\mathcal{H}_{\hbar}}=\int_{M}(\Psi,\Psi^{\prime})(x)f(x)d\nu(x),\qquad\Psi,\Psi^{\prime}\in\mathcal{H}_{\hbar}, (18)

When the spaces ℋℏsubscriptℋPlanck-constant-over-2-pi\mathcal{H}_{\hbar} are conveniently defined, the family (Tℏ,ℏ∈Λ)subscript𝑇Planck-constant-over-2-piPlanck-constant-over-2-piΛ(T_{\hbar},\hbar\in{\Lambda}) satisfies usual semi-classical properties. Typically, for a Kähler manifold M𝑀M equipped with a positive line bundle L𝐿L, we choose Λ:={ℏ=1/k,k∈ℕ∗}assignΛformulae-sequencePlanck-constant-over-2-pi1𝑘𝑘superscriptℕ{\Lambda}:=\{\hbar=1/k,\;k\in{\mathbb{N}}^{*}\}, Lℏ:=L⊗kassignsubscript𝐿Planck-constant-over-2-pisuperscript𝐿tensor-productabsent𝑘L_{\hbar}:=L^{\otimes k} and define ℋℏsubscriptℋPlanck-constant-over-2-pi\mathcal{H}_{\hbar} as the space of holomorphic sections of Lksuperscript𝐿𝑘L^{k}. These definitions can be extended to any quantizable M𝑀M, cf. [15] or [7] for instance. For the purpose of this appendix, we only need that the reproducing kernel of ℋℏsubscriptℋPlanck-constant-over-2-pi\mathcal{H}_{\hbar} satisfies the two estimates (22) and (23).

In the definition (18) of Tℏ​(f)subscript𝑇Planck-constant-over-2-pi𝑓T_{\hbar}(f), instead of a smooth function f𝑓f, we can more generally consider any distribution f∈𝒞−∞​(M)𝑓superscript𝒞𝑀f\in\mathcal{C}^{-\infty}(M). Indeed, in equation (18), the pointwise scalar product (Ψ,Ψ′)ΨsuperscriptΨ′(\Psi,\Psi^{\prime}) is a smooth function, so the integral of f𝑓f against (Ψ,Ψ′)​d​νΨsuperscriptΨ′𝑑𝜈(\Psi,\Psi^{\prime})d\nu still makes sense and defines an endomorphism Tℏ​(f)subscript𝑇Planck-constant-over-2-pi𝑓T_{\hbar}(f). The map Tℏ:𝒞−∞​(M)→End⁡(ℋℏ):subscript𝑇Planck-constant-over-2-pi→superscript𝒞𝑀EndsubscriptℋPlanck-constant-over-2-piT_{\hbar}:\mathcal{C}^{-\infty}(M)\rightarrow\operatorname{End}(\mathcal{H}_{\hbar}) is linear and positive in the sense that Tℏ​(f)⩾0subscript𝑇Planck-constant-over-2-pi𝑓0T_{\hbar}(f)\geqslant 0 when f⩾0𝑓0f\geqslant 0. The question is whether the asymptotic properties of Tℏ​(f)subscript𝑇Planck-constant-over-2-pi𝑓T_{\hbar}(f) still holds, in particular the estimates of the trace and the product.

Proposition A.1.

For any f∈𝒞−∞​(M)𝑓superscript𝒞𝑀f\in\mathcal{C}^{-\infty}(M), we have

tr⁡(Tℏ​(f))=(2​π​ℏ)−n​(∫Mf​𝑑ν)​(1+𝒪​(ℏ))trsubscript𝑇Planck-constant-over-2-pi𝑓superscript2𝜋Planck-constant-over-2-pi𝑛subscript𝑀𝑓differential-d𝜈1𝒪Planck-constant-over-2-pi\operatorname{tr}(T_{\hbar}(f))=(2\pi\hbar)^{-n}\Bigl{(}\int_{M}fd\nu\Bigr{)}(1+\mathcal{O}(\hbar))

The proof is an immediate generalization of the smooth case and will be given later. For the multiplicative properties of Tℏsubscript𝑇Planck-constant-over-2-piT_{\hbar}, the regularity is crucial. For instance let us recall two estimates proved in [2]. Let Rℏ​(f,g)=Tℏ​(f)​Tℏ​(g)−Tℏ​(f​g)subscript𝑅Planck-constant-over-2-pi𝑓𝑔subscript𝑇Planck-constant-over-2-pi𝑓subscript𝑇Planck-constant-over-2-pi𝑔subscript𝑇Planck-constant-over-2-pi𝑓𝑔R_{\hbar}(f,g)=T_{\hbar}(f)T_{\hbar}(g)-T_{\hbar}(fg). When f𝑓f and g𝑔g are only assumed to be continuous, ‖Rℏ​(f,g)‖normsubscript𝑅Planck-constant-over-2-pi𝑓𝑔\|R_{\hbar}(f,g)\| tends to 00 in the semiclassical limit ℏ→0→Planck-constant-over-2-pi0\hbar\rightarrow 0. It is not proved that these estimates are sharp, but we believe they are.

Our goal is to extend these multiplicative properties to a subalgebra of L∞​(M)superscript𝐿𝑀L^{\infty}(M) containing the characteristic functions of smooth domains. By a smooth domain, we mean a 0-codimensional smooth submanifold with boundary. For any endomorphism T𝑇T of ℋℏsubscriptℋPlanck-constant-over-2-pi\mathcal{H}_{\hbar}, we introduce its Schatten norm normalized by the dimension d​(ℏ)=dimℋℏ𝑑Planck-constant-over-2-pidimensionsubscriptℋPlanck-constant-over-2-pid(\hbar)=\dim\mathcal{H}_{\hbar},

Theorem A.2.
  1. 1.

    Any smooth domain of M𝑀M is a good set.

  2. 2.

    The good sets form an algebra, that is they are closed under taking complement, finite intersection and finite union.

  3. 3.

    If f,g∈L∞​(M)𝑓𝑔superscript𝐿𝑀f,g\in L^{\infty}(M) are simple functions, then f​g𝑓𝑔fg is simple and

    Tℏ​(f)​Tℏ​(g)=Tℏ​(f​g)+𝒪2​(ℏ1/4).subscript𝑇Planck-constant-over-2-pi𝑓subscript𝑇Planck-constant-over-2-pi𝑔subscript𝑇Planck-constant-over-2-pi𝑓𝑔subscript𝒪2superscriptPlanck-constant-over-2-pi14T_{\hbar}(f)T_{\hbar}(g)=T_{\hbar}(fg)+\mathcal{O}_{2}(\hbar^{1/4}).
  4. 4.

    If f𝑓f is simple and takes only non-negative values, then f1/2superscript𝑓12f^{1/2} is simple and

    Tℏ​(f)1/2=Tℏ​(f1/2)+𝒪4​(ℏ1/8).subscript𝑇Planck-constant-over-2-pisuperscript𝑓12subscript𝑇Planck-constant-over-2-pisuperscript𝑓12subscript𝒪4superscriptPlanck-constant-over-2-pi18T_{\hbar}(f)^{1/2}=T_{\hbar}(f^{1/2})+\mathcal{O}_{4}(\hbar^{1/8}).

Interestingly, only the first assertion relies on the estimates (22) and (23) of the Bergman kernel. The proof of the other assertions is independent and does not use any difficult result.

The curious reader can think to the case where M𝑀M is the two-sphere and A𝐴A a hemisphere. In this case, we can explicitely compute the spectrum of Tℏ​(χA)subscript𝑇Planck-constant-over-2-pisubscript𝜒𝐴T_{\hbar}(\chi_{A}) as we learned from [11], cf. also [3]. ∎

Proof of assertion 4 of Theorem A.2.

Using that the square root is an operator monotone function, we have

‖Sℏ​(f)−Tℏ​(f)‖4⩽∥|Sℏ​(f)−Tℏ​(f)|∥4=‖Sℏ​(f)−Tℏ​(f)‖21/2subscriptnormsubscript𝑆Planck-constant-over-2-pi𝑓subscript𝑇Planck-constant-over-2-pi𝑓4subscriptdelimited-∥∥subscript𝑆Planck-constant-over-2-pi𝑓subscript𝑇Planck-constant-over-2-pi𝑓4superscriptsubscriptnormsubscript𝑆Planck-constant-over-2-pi𝑓subscript𝑇Planck-constant-over-2-pi𝑓212\|\sqrt{S_{\hbar}(f)}-\sqrt{T_{\hbar}(f)}\|_{4}\leqslant\bigl{\|}\sqrt{|S_{\hbar}(f)-T_{\hbar}(f)|}\bigr{\|}_{4}=\|S_{\hbar}(f)-T_{\hbar}(f)\|_{2}^{1/2}

and the right hand-side is a 𝒪​(ℏ1/8)𝒪superscriptPlanck-constant-over-2-pi18\mathcal{O}(\hbar^{1/8}) by (34). In other words, Tℏ​(f1/2)=Tℏ​(f)1/2+𝒪4​(ℏ1/8).subscript𝑇Planck-constant-over-2-pisuperscript𝑓12subscript𝑇Planck-constant-over-2-pisuperscript𝑓12subscript𝒪4superscriptPlanck-constant-over-2-pi18T_{\hbar}(f^{1/2})=T_{\hbar}(f)^{1/2}+\mathcal{O}_{4}(\hbar^{1/8}). ∎

Proof of corollary A.3.

By assertion 4 of Theorem A.2 and (30), we have

1d​(ℏ)​tr⁡(Pℏ∗​Pℏ)=1d​(ℏ)​tr⁡(Qℏ∗​Qℏ)+𝒪​(ℏ1/8)1𝑑Planck-constant-over-2-pitrsuperscriptsubscript𝑃Planck-constant-over-2-pisubscript𝑃Planck-constant-over-2-pi1𝑑Planck-constant-over-2-pitrsuperscriptsubscript𝑄Planck-constant-over-2-pisubscript𝑄Planck-constant-over-2-pi𝒪superscriptPlanck-constant-over-2-pi18\frac{1}{d(\hbar)}\operatorname{tr}(P_{\hbar}^{*}P_{\hbar})=\frac{1}{d(\hbar)}\operatorname{tr}(Q_{\hbar}^{*}Q_{\hbar})+\mathcal{O}(\hbar^{1/8})

with Qℏ=Tℏ​(f1)​…​Tℏ​(fm)subscript𝑄Planck-constant-over-2-pisubscript𝑇Planck-constant-over-2-pisubscript𝑓1…subscript𝑇Planck-constant-over-2-pisubscript𝑓𝑚Q_{\hbar}=T_{\hbar}(f_{1})\ldots T_{\hbar}(f_{m}). By assertion 3 of Theorem A.2,

Qℏ∗​Qℏ=Tℏ​(f1​…​fm)+𝒪​(ℏ1/4).superscriptsubscript𝑄Planck-constant-over-2-pisubscript𝑄Planck-constant-over-2-pisubscript𝑇Planck-constant-over-2-pisubscript𝑓1…subscript𝑓𝑚𝒪superscriptPlanck-constant-over-2-pi14Q_{\hbar}^{*}Q_{\hbar}=T_{\hbar}(f_{1}\ldots f_{m})+\mathcal{O}(\hbar^{1/4}).

So by (30) and Proposition A.1,

1d​(ℏ)​tr⁡(Qℏ∗​Qℏ)=1ν​(M)​∫Mf1​…​fm​𝑑ν+𝒪​(ℏ1/4)1𝑑Planck-constant-over-2-pitrsuperscriptsubscript𝑄Planck-constant-over-2-pisubscript𝑄Planck-constant-over-2-pi1𝜈𝑀subscript𝑀subscript𝑓1…subscript𝑓𝑚differential-d𝜈𝒪superscriptPlanck-constant-over-2-pi14\frac{1}{d(\hbar)}\operatorname{tr}(Q_{\hbar}^{*}Q_{\hbar})=\frac{1}{\nu(M)}\int_{M}f_{1}\ldots f_{m}\;d\nu+\mathcal{O}(\hbar^{1/4})

and the result follows. ∎
